div1.head: Jim to Mr. Paul Rockwell, Monday May 3rd [1915]
div1.p: Your card just received and I presume that by now you have the letter I sent back by Andrew for you. Oh, yes I got your letter and the address is quite right. Your postal took seven days to arrive.

I’m awfully glad you are en route for reforme and hope it goes through soon.
We had a hell of a fight out here the other night with the result that four trenches were taken and a hundred and fifty Boches. I saw them right afterwards. They were the “crummiest” looking lot you ever saw and afraid they were going to get killed. a A Sarge^nt kept saying “Nicht capute!” Don’t kill me. When they saw us they had a fit thinking us English.

I’ve never heard
such a racket as the artillery made. When it was going strong I thought there wouldn’t be a tree standing or a stone on top of another. We work between the artillery and the trenches so get the benefit of the racket.— And it was some racket as you know. A flock of aeros were up all day and as a result we had a few balls of shrapnel
drop down near us when the anti air craft guns went off. A shell burst fifty feet back of one of our fellows while he was running his ambulance after wounded and last night an eclat of an obus tore off the front of the top of Davis’ car. It missed his bean by ten inches. And lifted his car over on two wheels, so close was the explosion.

We have many evacuation
cases besides our work back of the trenches and some of the rides are quite beautiful. We follow the winding course of a beautiful river. The road runs at the side of the velvet green bottom lands and between rows of beautiful tall trees that are now covered with the delicate green of spring. The hillsides have that entrancing miniature gardenlike appearance that
the patches of green grass, brown soil, and yellow mustard plants give. Its all very very pretty and makes one appreciate living. I believe I have said before that one has to leave Paris to realize fully the meaning of “La Belle France.”

The Boches have established a regular schedule for us at our base now and we know when to expect the shells to come in. Its
different up here where we’re so near. The soldiers that rest from the trenches prefer to be back in them as far as safety is concerned at our advance point.

I carried my first Boche the other day. He was in the hell of a mess and croaked soon after getting to the hospital. You see its quite impossible to give anything but very superficial aid out here and the men
that are not strong and who are very badly wounded can’t make the grade. The worst thing now is the damned crapoullot [sic--crapouillot]. You know the little cans one lights with a cigarette and tosses over into the other fellows trench. The wounds are horrible. In one place here the trenches are only thirty inches apart. A soldier back from there told me they put a sand bag up and the
Germans swiped it. The French got another, held it up, and when the German reached across another Frenchman clouted him over the dome with a shovel.

Often the Boches yell out: “Eh Comarade” and the French used to fall for it thinking they were going to give them selves up. When they looked out a hail of crapoullots [sic] would meet them. Dirty bunch those Germans.
God knows when they will be shoved back tho [sic].
Our kodaks have been taken from us here. Otherwise I could get some wonderful pictures.

I’m glad She’s back and I suppose you are talking over your motor trip and the number of rooms you’ll have for the drivers in your new garage. Don’t forget the sideboard and the twin carafes that always go with a newly married
couple.

By the way I have scared up a village belle who has promised me I may call on her at night and [cause avec elle dans le jardin.] I get about two nights off a week and have a way of sneaking into my billet after eight so here’s where I improve my French. I suppose it will end in a dose, but trust not.

I’m rather surprised,
not to mention, piqued that I haven’t had a line even from the Guerin individual.
Well old war horse get that reforme business thru [sic] with for I hate to think of your going back dans les trenches.

closer.salute:
Hope to hear from you soon.
Yours
closer.seg:
James McConnell
S.S. Americaine .Y.
